items.title: European leaders warn of ‘downward spiral’ after Trump threatens tariffs over Greenland – Europe live
items.standfirst: Denmark, Norway, Sweden, the UK, France, Germany, the Netherlands and Finland will face tariffs from 1 FebruaryWhat do people in Greenland think of Donald Trump and his threats to take over the island? The Guardian’s Miranda Bryant and Lauren Hurrell take a look.Reuters estimated that thousands of protesters attended the “Hands Off Greenland” rallies around Denmark on Saturday, chanting “Greenland is not for sale” and waving Greenland’s red and white “Erfalasorput” flag. Continue reading...
items.content: Denmark, Norway, Sweden, the UK, France, Germany, the Netherlands and Finland will face tariffs from 1 FebruaryWhat do people in Greenland think of Donald Trump and his threats to take over the island? The Guardian’s Miranda Bryant and Lauren Hurrell take a look.Reuters estimated that thousands of protesters attended the “Hands Off Greenland” rallies around Denmark on Saturday, chanting “Greenland is not for sale” and waving Greenland’s red and white “Erfalasorput” flag. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump threatens 25% tariff on European allies until Denmark sells Greenland to US
items.standfirst: Heads of state across Europe respond in solidarity with Denmark and Greenland, and boycott of World Cup suggestedDonald Trump threatened a 25% tariff on a slew of European countries including Denmark, Germany, France and the UK – until the US is allowed to purchase Greenland, in an extraordinary escalation of the president’s bid to claim the autonomous Danish territory.In a lengthy post on Saturday on Truth Social, Trump said he would impose a 10% tariff on Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and Finland beginning 1 February, “on any and all goods sent to the United States of America”. Continue reading...
items.content: Heads of state across Europe respond in solidarity with Denmark and Greenland, and boycott of World Cup suggestedDonald Trump threatened a 25% tariff on a slew of European countries including Denmark, Germany, France and the UK – until the US is allowed to purchase Greenland, in an extraordinary escalation of the president’s bid to claim the autonomous Danish territory.In a lengthy post on Saturday on Truth Social, Trump said he would impose a 10% tariff on Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and Finland beginning 1 February, “on any and all goods sent to the United States of America”. Continue reading...

items.title: EU vows coordinated response to Trump's tariffs threat over Greenland sale

items.title: Trump’s tariff threat is an attempt to divide Europe and quash opposition over Greenland
items.standfirst: Using one of his favourite weapons to win an argument, the US president underlines the unstable nature of any deal he makesDonald Trump’s threat to impose fresh tariffs on eight European countries – UK, Norway and six EU member states – is a wrecking ball to the carefully stitched deals he concluded with those countries last summer.The two biggest voting blocs in the European parliament, the European People’s Party (EPP) and the Socialists & Democrats (S&Ds), said on Saturday night the deal with the EU cannot be approved in the present circumstances. Continue reading...
items.content: Using one of his favourite weapons to win an argument, the US president underlines the unstable nature of any deal he makesDonald Trump’s threat to impose fresh tariffs on eight European countries – UK, Norway and six EU member states – is a wrecking ball to the carefully stitched deals he concluded with those countries last summer.The two biggest voting blocs in the European parliament, the European People’s Party (EPP) and the Socialists & Democrats (S&Ds), said on Saturday night the deal with the EU cannot be approved in the present circumstances. items.standfirst: Prime minister and opposition politicians condemn threat to impose 10% tariff unless deal reached to buy the Arctic islandKeir Starmer has said Donald Trump’s decision to impose 10% tariffs on the UK and seven other European countries over Greenland was “completely wrong”.The US president said the levies would apply from 1 February to Nato members – including the UK, France and Germany – who have deployed troops to the territory in response to growing uncertainty over its future. items.title: Iran's Khamenei calls for crackdown on 'seditionists' after brutally repressing protests
items.standfirst: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei called for "domestic criminals" to face swift punishment, accusing "seditionists" of being responsible for the death of thousands of people during the recent protest wave. Rights groups have put the death toll of the government's crackdown in the thousands.
items.content: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei called for "domestic criminals" to face swift punishment, accusing "seditionists" of being responsible for the death of thousands of people during the recent protest wave. Rights groups have put the death toll of the government's crackdown in the thousands.

items.title: Iran’s supreme leader concedes thousands killed in unrest

Some of those were killed “brutally and inhumanely,” Khamenei said without offering detail in a…

items.title: Rapper describes 'massacre' on Iran's streets - as supreme leader says thousands killed in protests
items.standfirst: An Iranian rapper who took part in the country's protests has described "a massacre on the streets", suggesting foreign forces have been brought in to stamp out the protests.
items.content: An Iranian rapper who took part in the country's protests has described "a massacre on the streets", suggesting foreign forces have been brought in to stamp out the protests.

items.title: Ali Khamenei says thousands killed in Iran protests, some in ‘inhuman, savage manner’
items.standfirst: Supreme leader blames US for death toll and calls Donald Trump a criminal for support of demonstrationsThe Iranian supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has acknowledged for the first time that thousands of people were killed during the protests that rocked Iran over the last two weeks.In a speech on Thursday, Khamenei said that thousands of people had been killed, “some in an inhuman, savage manner”, and blamed the US for the death toll. The supreme leader railed against the US president, Donald Trump, whom he called a “criminal” for his support of demonstrations, and called for strict punishment of protesters. Continue reading...
items.content: Supreme leader blames US for death toll and calls Donald Trump a criminal for support of demonstrationsThe Iranian supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has acknowledged for the first time that thousands of people were killed during the protests that rocked Iran over the last two weeks.In a speech on Thursday, Khamenei said that thousands of people had been killed, “some in an inhuman, savage manner”, and blamed the US for the death toll. The supreme leader railed against the US president, Donald Trump, whom he called a “criminal” for his support of demonstrations, and called for strict punishment of protesters. Continue reading...

items.content: Museveni claims victory in Uganda's contested election as opposition leader Bobi Wine goes into hiding amid chaos, violence and accusations of fraud.(Image credit: Luis TATO)

items.title: Uganda's President Yoweri Museveni wins seventh term as rival Bobi Wine rejects 'fake results'
items.standfirst: Uganda's incumbent President Yoweri Museveni won a seventh term in office, official results showed Saturday, allowing the former guerrilla to extend his four-decade rule of the East African country. His main opponent, Bobi Wine, remains in hiding after security forces raided his home.
items.content: Uganda's incumbent President Yoweri Museveni won a seventh term in office, official results showed Saturday, allowing the former guerrilla to extend his four-decade rule of the East African country. His main opponent, Bobi Wine, remains in hiding after security forces raided his home.

items.content: Museveni, 81, secured 71.65 percent support, electoral commission says, after contentious election campaign.

items.title: Canada announces trade deal with China on EVs, canola
items.standfirst: Canada and China struck an initial trade deal on Friday that will slash tariffs on electric vehicles and ⁠canola, as both nations promised to tear down trade barriers while forging new strategic ties during Prime Minister Mark Carney's visit. FRANCE 24 speaks to Jean-Baptiste Monnier, Asia Centre Vice President, to shed more light on the implications of the trade agreement.
items.content: Canada and China struck an initial trade deal on Friday that will slash tariffs on electric vehicles and ⁠canola, as both nations promised to tear down trade barriers while forging new strategic ties during Prime Minister Mark Carney's visit. items.title: Canada PM hails strategic partnership with China to adapt to ‘new global realities’
items.standfirst: Mark Carney holds talks with Xi Jinping on rare Beijing trip as Canada seeks to diversify trade links away from USBusiness live – latest updatesCanada’s prime minister, Mark Carney, has hailed a “new strategic partnership” with China as he held talks in Beijing with President Xi Jinping, the first visit by a Canadian leader in eight years.Addressing Xi in the Great Hall of the People, Carney said: “Together we can build on the best of what this relationship has been in the past to create a new one adapted to new global realities.” Continue reading...

items.title: Trump Wants Big Tech to Pay for Power | Bloomberg Tech 1/16/2026
items.standfirst: Bloomberg’s Ed Ludlow discusses the plan laid out by the Trump administration and several states to have tech companies pay for surging energy prices following the rise of AI data centers. Plus, AI coding startup Replit nears a $9 billion valuation in a new funding round. And the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, Andrew Ferguson discusses acquihires, consumer protection and AI regulation. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Bloomberg’s Ed Ludlow discusses the plan laid out by the Trump administration and several states to have tech companies pay for surging energy prices following the rise of AI data centers. Plus, AI coding startup Replit nears a $9 billion valuation in a new funding round. And the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, Andrew Ferguson discusses acquihires, consumer protection and AI regulation. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: FTC Chair: Acquihires Won’t Be a Path Around Antitrust
items.standfirst: FTC Chairman Andrew Ferguson spoke to Bloomberg's Ed Ludlow. He made clear that acquihires will not be allowed as cover to evade antitrust scrutiny. Ferguson said the FTC will look beyond headcount to factors like access to technology, IP, and stock-based consideration when evaluating whether talent deals function as de facto mergers. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: FTC Chairman Andrew Ferguson spoke to Bloomberg's Ed Ludlow. He made clear that acquihires will not be allowed as cover to evade antitrust scrutiny. Ferguson said the FTC will look beyond headcount to factors like access to technology, IP, and stock-based consideration when evaluating whether talent deals function as de facto mergers. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: US Is Scrutinizing Big Tech Talent Acquisitions, FTC Chief Says
items.standfirst: The US Federal Trade Commission is taking a closer look at moves by major tech companies to hire away the employees of a startup instead of buying the venture outright, the agency’s Chairman Andrew Ferguson said, addressing a growing practice seen as a way to avoid antitrust review.
items.content: The US Federal Trade Commission is taking a closer look at moves by major tech companies to hire away the employees of a startup instead of buying the venture outright, the agency’s Chairman Andrew Ferguson said, addressing a growing practice seen as a way to avoid antitrust review.

items.title: FTC Will Review Acquihires, Chair Ferguson Says
items.standfirst: Tech companies no longer need creative workarounds, like acquihires, to get M&A deals through, says Federal Trade Commission Chair Andrew Ferguson. Ferguson says the commission will review these deals to make sure they comply with the law. He joins Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Tech." (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Tech companies no longer need creative workarounds, like acquihires, to get M&A deals through, says Federal Trade Commission Chair Andrew Ferguson. items.title: Kurdish granted national language status in Syria
items.standfirst: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa issued a decree on Friday declaring Kurdish a "national language", in an apparent gesture of good will towards the minority following clashes in recent days. The decree is the first formal recognition of Kurdish national rights since Syria's independence in 1946.
items.content: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa issued a decree on Friday declaring Kurdish a "national language", in an apparent gesture of good will towards the minority following clashes in recent days. The decree is the first formal recognition of Kurdish national rights since Syria's independence in 1946.
